factoid: The floor of the stage consisted of smooth boards.
The sides of the stage had painted cardboard representing trees.
The back of the stage had a cloth stretched over boards.
Some girls in red bodices and white skirts sat in the center of the stage.
One very fat girl in a white silk dress sat apart on a low bench.
A piece of green cardboard was glued to the back of the low bench.
All the girls sang something.
The girl in white went up to the prompter’s box after the girls finished singing.
A man with tight silk trousers over his stout legs, holding a plume and a dagger, went up to the girl in white and began singing, waving his arms about.
The man in the tight trousers sang alone first.
The girl in white sang after the man sang alone.
The man and the girl in white paused while the orchestra played.
The man fingered the hand of the girl in white while waiting for the beat to start singing with her.
The man and the girl in white sang together.
Everyone in the theater began clapping and shouting.
The man and the girl in white, who represented lovers, began smiling.
The man and the girl in white spread out their arms.
The man and the girl in white bowed.
Natásha had a life in the country.
Natásha was in a present serious mood.
All this seemed grotesque and amazing to Natásha.
Natásha could not follow the opera.
Natásha could not even listen to the music.
Natásha saw only the painted cardboard.
Natásha saw queerly dressed men and women who moved, spoke, and sang so strangely in that brilliant light.
Natásha knew what the performance was meant to represent.
The performance was pretentiously false and unnatural.
Natásha first felt ashamed for the actors.
Natásha then felt amused at the actors.
Natásha looked at the faces of the audience.
Natásha looked at the faces of the audience seeking in them the sense of ridicule and perplexity she experienced.
The audience seemed attentive to what was happening on the stage.
The audience expressed delight.
The delight seemed feigned to Natásha.
Natásha thought, "I suppose it has to be like this!".
Natásha kept looking round at the rows of pomaded heads in the stalls.
Natásha kept looking round at the seminude women in the boxes.
Natásha especially looked at Hélène in the next box.
Hélène was apparently quite unclothed.
Hélène sat with a quiet tranquil smile.
Hélène did not take her eyes off the stage.
The bright light flooded the whole place.
The warm air was heated by the crowd.
Natásha felt the bright light.
Natásha felt the warm air heated by the crowd.
Natásha began to pass into a state of intoxication little by little.
Natásha had not experienced that state of intoxication for a long while.
Natásha did not realize who she was.
Natásha did not realize where she was.
Natásha did not realize what was going on before her.
Strange fancies passed through Natásha’s mind as she looked and thought.
The idea occurred to Natásha of jumping onto the edge of the box and singing the aria the actress was singing.
Natásha wished to touch with her fan an old gentleman sitting not far from her.
Natásha wished to lean over to Hélène and tickle her.
At a quiet moment before the commencement of a song, a door leading to the stalls on the side nearest the Rostóvs’ box creaked.
The steps of a belated arrival were heard.
Shinshín whispered, "There’s Kurágin!".
Countess Bezúkhova turned smiling to the newcomer.
Natásha followed the direction of Countess Bezúkhova’s look.
Natásha saw an exceptionally handsome adjutant approaching their box.
The adjutant had a self‑assured yet courteous bearing.
The adjutant was Anatole Kurágin.
Natásha had seen Anatole Kurágin long ago at the ball in Petersburg.
Anatole Kurágin wore an adjutant’s uniform.
Anatole Kurágin had one epaulet.
Anatole Kurágin had a shoulder knot.
Anatole Kurágin moved with a restrained swagger.
Anatole Kurágin was good-looking.
Anatole Kurágin had a handsome face.
Anatole Kurágin’s face wore an expression of good‑humored complacency and gaiety.
The performance was proceeding.
Anatole Kurágin walked deliberately down the carpeted gangway.
Anatole Kurágin’s sword and spurs slightly jingled.
Anatole Kurágin’s perfumed head was held high.
Anatole Kurágin looked at Natásha.
Anatole Kurágin approached his sister.
Anatole Kurágin laid his well gloved hand on the edge of his sister's box.
Anatole Kurágin nodded to his sister.
Anatole Kurágin leaned forward and asked a question with a motion toward Natásha.
Anatole Kurágin said, "Mais charmante!".
Anatole Kurágin was referring to Natásha.
Natásha did not exactly hear Anatole Kurágin's words.
Natásha understood Anatole Kurágin's words from the movement of his lips.
Anatole Kurágin took his place in the first row of the stalls.
Anatole Kurágin sat down beside Dólokhov.
Anatole Kurágin nudged with his elbow in a friendly and offhand way.
Others treated Dólokhov fawningly.
Anatole Kurágin winked at Dólokhov gaily.
Anatole Kurágin smiled.
Anatole Kurágin rested his foot against the orchestra screen.
The count remarked, "How like the brother is to the sister."
The count remarked, "And how handsome they both are!".
Shinshín lowered his voice.
Shinshín began to tell the count of some intrigue of Kurágin’s in Moscow.
Natásha tried to overhear Shinshín because he had said Natásha was "charmante".
